adambuttrick
07/27/2022, 16:45:32 | 07/27/2022, 17:51:34
comment_text: Original request was for Weill Cornell Medical College, a sub-entity of both Weill Cornell Medicine and Cornell itself. I believe the appropriate record here would be for Weill Cornell Medicine, which includes both the hospital and its medical college. Conversely, we have the precedent of [Weill Cornell Medical College in Qatar](https://ror.org/05v5hg569), which would indicate that the NYC college is also in scope. Would like to hear others thoughts. Weill Cornell Medicine previously existed as grid.471410.7/https://ror.org/02r109517, before it was removed by GRID when we were synced with their data. If added, we would reinstate with these IDs.

While its domain is under the Cornell umbrella, Weill Cornell Medicine is located separate from the main campus and exists in partnership with other NYC area hospitals. Funds and employs researchers and has solid affiliation usage, so would otherwise be in scope.

comment_text: Ooh, absolutely we should have this, a major medical research facility. I guess this was part of GRID's purge of medical schools but it really is very separate from the main university. Also, we have several Cornell "colleges" that are colocated in Ithaca as full ROR records (see child organizations on the main Cornell record https://ror.org/05bnh6r87, I guess due to a dual role as a state agricultural university in addition to being a major private liberal arts university. An another note I wonder if we should also have an additional ROR record for Cornell Tech - https://tech.cornell.edu - or maybe just for the "Jacobs Technion-Cornell Institute" which is a joint institute there with Technion (Israel) as the other parent. comment_text: I think we're pretty inconsistent right now with medical schools vs their associated medical facilities/hospitals; I'm not remembering if we had any specific policy on this. I'd keep them combined for now pending any consistent rule on medical schools.

odonner1
07/29/2022, 19:31:13 | 07/29/2022, 19:31:13
comment_text: As the requester for this one, I want to add a comment. In general. I've been noticing that researchers have trouble with ROR when they are affiliated with a medical school. They have always specified "medical college" or "school of medicine" and when completing forms during submission, they do the same, using the med school name. We currently allow authors to enter names they wish for their address information, even if autocomplete does not find an entry in ROR. That's becoming a problem for us, and we are going to start requiring a ROR institution. This is surely going to cause issues for authors who insist on using the med school name. I think it would be helpful for medical schools to have distinct but related RORs.

---
adambuttrick
07/29/2022, 19:56:56 | 07/29/2022, 20:01:04
comment_text: @odonner1 Thank you for that additional context. We will take it under advisement in how we address medical schools moving forward.

More generally, we advise against requiring ROR IDs in integrations. There will always be organizations that are out of scope for ROR, but are otherwise appropriate as affiliations. Likewise, we are not always able to add records for organizations at the same pace with which they are being used in various scholarly publishing systems, even if those organizations are in scope for the registry.

---
odonner1
07/29/2022, 20:03:59 | 07/29/2022, 20:03:59
comment_text: Understood, and we can talk more offline about how we plan to require, there will be an out. However, ROR is driving our R&P deal eligibility checks as well as our Open Access Switchboard workflow, so it's a real problem when an organization does not have a ROR, or the searchable name differs enough from the ROR entry that authors cannot find the entry, and get frustrated, as with many med schools.
